content: The "Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001" reduces the maximum estate and gift tax rate to 45 percent by amending the table in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001" reduces the maximum estate and gift tax rate to 45 percent by amending the table in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Over $1,500,000, the tax is $555,800 plus 45% of the excess. Repeal of Phaseout of Graduated Rates and Effective Date for estates of decedents dying, and gifts made, after December 31, 2000. Unified Credit against estate and gift taxes replaced with unified exemption amount. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 amends the computation of estate tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax imposed is the excess of the tentative tax over the aggregate amount of tax payable on gifts made by the decedent after December 31, 1976. The tentative tax is calculated based on specific criteria outlined in the code. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 amends the computation of estate tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tentative tax is calculated based on the sum of the taxable estate and adjusted taxable gifts, minus the exemption amount of $10,000,000. Adjusted taxable gifts refer to gifts made by the decedent after December 31, 1976, excluding gifts included in the gross estate. The gift tax computation under the Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 is based on the excess of the tentative tax over the aggregate amount of tax payable for gifts made in preceding periods. The tentative tax is determined for each calendar year. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 calculates gift tax based on the excess of tentative tax over the total tax paid for gifts in previous years. Unified credits against estate and gift tax are repealed, with conforming amendments made to section 2011 of the tax code. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 makes amendments to various sections of the tax code, including striking certain references to the unified credit provided by section 2010. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 repealed section 2057 of the tax code and made changes to the credit and exemption amounts allowable for surviving spouses. The exemption amount for estate tax is determined based on the value of the decedent's gross estate in the US, with special rules for coordination with treaties. The Estate Tax Relief Act of 2001 reduces dollar amounts in subparagraphs (A) or (B) by any exemption allowed under section 2501 for gifts made by the decedent. The tax code is amended to change various sections, including section 6601(j)(2) and section 2010. The amendments apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after December 31, 2000. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN ANNUAL GIFT EXCLUSION AMOUNT. The annual gift exclusion amount is increased from $10,000 to $50,000 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This change applies to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after December 31, 2000.
